</section>		<section class="section definition-section" data-menu-title="Definition" id="content-body">
<section class="section main-article-chapter" data-menu-title="What is a data engineer?">
 <h3 class="section-title"><i class="icon" data-icon="1"></i>What is a data engineer?</h3>
 <p>A data engineer is an IT worker whose primary job is to prepare data for analytical or operational uses. These software engineers are typically responsible for building data pipelines to bring together information from different source systems. They integrate, consolidate and <a href="https://searchdatamanagement.techtarget.com/definition/data-scrubbing">cleanse data</a> and structure it for use in analytics applications. They aim to make data easily accessible and to optimize their organization's <a href="https://searchdatamanagement.techtarget.com/definition/big-data">big data</a> ecosystem.</p>
 <p>The amount of data an engineer works with varies with the organization, particularly with respect to its size. The bigger the company, the more complex the analytics architecture, and the <a href="https://searchdatamanagement.techtarget.com/definition/big-data-engineer">more data the engineer</a> will be responsible for. Certain industries are more data-intensive, including healthcare, retail and financial services.</p>
 <p>Data engineers work in conjunction with data science teams, <a href="https://searchcio.techtarget.com/feature/The-future-of-trust-must-be-built-on-data-transparency">improving data transparency</a> and enabling businesses to make more trustworthy business decisions.</p>
 <figure class="main-article-image full-col" data-img-fullsize="https://cdn.ttgtmedia.com/rms/onlineimages/data_management-comparing_roles.png">
  <img data-src="https://cdn.ttgtmedia.com/rms/onlineimages/data_management-comparing_roles_mobile.png" class="lazy" data-srcset="https://cdn.ttgtmedia.com/rms/onlineimages/data_management-comparing_roles_mobile.png 960w,https://cdn.ttgtmedia.com/rms/onlineimages/data_management-comparing_roles_desktop.png 1280w" alt="how data management jobs compare">
  <figcaption>
   <i class="icon pictures" data-icon="z"></i>See how eight different data management jobs stack up against one another other.
  </figcaption>
  <div class="main-article-image-enlarge">
   <i class="icon" data-icon="w"></i>
  </div>
 </figure>
</section>     
<section class="section main-article-chapter" data-menu-title="The data engineer role">
 <h3 class="section-title"><i class="icon" data-icon="1"></i>The data engineer role</h3>
 <p>Data engineers focus on collecting and preparing data for use by <a href="https://searchenterpriseai.techtarget.com/definition/data-scientist">data scientists</a> and analysts. They take on three main roles as follows:</p>
 <ul class="default-list"> 
  <li><strong> Generalists. </strong>Data engineers with a general focus typically work on small teams, doing end-to-end data collection, intake and processing. They may have more skill than most data engineers, but less knowledge of systems architecture. A data scientist looking to become a data engineer would fit well into the generalist role.</li> 
 </ul>
 <p style="padding-left: 30px;">A project a generalist data engineer might undertake for a small, metro-area food delivery service would be to create a <a href="https://searchbusinessanalytics.techtarget.com/definition/business-intelligence-dashboard">dashboard</a> that displays the number of deliveries made each day for the past month and forecasts the delivery volume for the following month.</p>
 <ul class="default-list"> 
  <li><strong>Pipeline-centric engineers. </strong>These data engineers typically work on a midsize data analytics team and more complicated data science projects across distributed systems. Midsize and large companies are more likely to need this role.</li> 
 </ul>
 <p style="padding-left: 30px;">A regional food delivery company might undertake a pipeline-centric project to create a tool for data scientists and analysts to search <a href="https://whatis.techtarget.com/definition/metadata">metadata</a> for information about deliveries. They might look at distance driven and drive time required for deliveries in the past month, then use that data in a predictive algorithm to see what it means for the company's future business.</p>
 <ul class="default-list"> 
  <li><strong>Database-centric engineers.</strong> These data engineers are tasked with implementing, maintaining and populating analytics databases. This role typically exists at larger companies where data is distributed across several databases. The engineers work with pipelines, tune databases for efficient analysis and create table schemas using extract, transform, load (<a href="https://searchdatamanagement.techtarget.com/definition/Extract-Load-Transform-ELT">ETL</a>) methods. ETL is a process in which data is copied from several sources into a single destination system.</li> 
 </ul>
 <p style="padding-left: 30px;">A database-centric project at a large, multistate or national food delivery service would be to design an analytics database. In addition to creating the database, the data engineer would write the code to get data from where it's collected in the main application database into the analytics database.</p>
</section>        
<section class="section main-article-chapter" data-menu-title="Data engineer responsibilities">
 <h3 class="section-title"><i class="icon" data-icon="1"></i>Data engineer responsibilities</h3>
 <p>Data engineers often work as part of an analytics team alongside data scientists. The engineers provide data in usable formats to the data scientists who run queries and algorithms against the information for predictive analytics, <a href="https://searchenterpriseai.techtarget.com/definition/machine-learning-ML">machine learning</a> and data mining applications. Data engineers also deliver aggregated data to business executives and analysts and other end users so they can analyze it and apply the results to improving business operations.</p>
 <figure class="main-article-image full-col" data-img-fullsize="https://cdn.ttgtmedia.com/rms/onlineImages/data_management-data_analytics.png">
  <img data-src="https://cdn.ttgtmedia.com/rms/onlineImages/data_management-data_analytics_mobile.png" class="lazy" data-srcset="https://cdn.ttgtmedia.com/rms/onlineImages/data_management-data_analytics_mobile.png 960w,https://cdn.ttgtmedia.com/rms/onlineImages/data_management-data_analytics_desktop.png 1280w" alt="data engineer and data scientist responsibilities on a data analytics team">
  <figcaption>
   <i class="icon pictures" data-icon="z"></i>Data engineers and data scientists contribute different skills to the data analytics team.
  </figcaption>
  <div class="main-article-image-enlarge">
   <i class="icon" data-icon="w"></i>
  </div>
 </figure>
 <p>Data engineers deal with both <a href="https://searchcontentmanagement.techtarget.com/tip/Challenges-of-combining-structured-and-unstructured-data">structured and unstructured data</a>. Structured data is information that can be organized into a formatted repository like a database. Unstructured data -- such as text, images, audio and video files -- doesn't conform to conventional data models. Data engineers must understand different approaches to data architecture and applications to handle both data types. A variety of big data technologies, such as open source data ingestion and processing frameworks, are also part of the data engineer's toolkit.</p>
</section>    
<section class="section main-article-chapter" data-menu-title="Data engineer skill set">
 <h3 class="section-title"><i class="icon" data-icon="1"></i>Data engineer skill set</h3>
 <p>Data engineers are skilled in programming languages such as C#, Java, Python, R, Ruby, Scala and SQL. Python, R and SQL are the three most important languages data engineers use.</p>
 <p>Engineers need a good understanding of ETL tools and <a href="https://searchapparchitecture.techtarget.com/definition/REST-REpresentational-State-Transfer">REST-oriented APIs</a> for creating and managing data integration jobs. These skills also help in providing data analysts and business users with simplified access to prepared data sets.</p>
 <p>Data engineers must understand data warehouses and data lakes and how they work. For instance, <a href="https://searchdatamanagement.techtarget.com/definition/Hadoop-data-lake">Hadoop data lakes</a> that offload the processing and storage work of established enterprise data warehouses support the big data analytics efforts data engineers work on.</p>
 <p>Data engineers must also understand NoSQL databases and Apache Spark systems, which are becoming common components of data workflows. Data engineers should have a knowledge of relational database systems as well, such as MySQL and PostgreSQL. Another focus is <a href="https://searchbusinessanalytics.techtarget.com/definition/Lambda-architecture">Lambda architecture</a>, which supports unified data pipelines for batch and real-time processing.</p>
 <p>Business intelligence (<a href="https://searchbusinessanalytics.techtarget.com/definition/business-intelligence-BI">BI</a>) platforms and the ability to configure them are another important focus for data engineers. With BI platforms, they can establish connections among data warehouses, data lakes and other data sources. Engineers must know how to work with the interactive dashboards BI platforms use.</p>
 <p>Although machine learning is more in the data scientist's or the machine learning engineer's skill set, data engineers must understand it, as well, to be able to prepare data for machine learning platforms. They should know how to deploy machine learning algorithms and gain insights from them.</p>
 <p>Lastly, knowledge of <a href="https://searchdatacenter.techtarget.com/definition/Unix">Unix</a>-based operating systems (OS) is important. Unix, Solaris and <a href="https://searchdatacenter.techtarget.com/definition/Linux-operating-system">Linux</a> provide functionality and root access that other OSes -- such as Mac OS and Windows -- don't. They give the user more control over the OS, which is useful for data engineers. </p>
 <div class="youtube-iframe-container">
  <iframe id="ytplayer-0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/EEu5eZaIHig?autoplay=0&modestbranding=1&rel=0&widget_referrer=https://searchdatamanagement.techtarget.com/definition/data-engineer&enablejsapi=1&origin=https://searchdatamanagement.techtarget.com" type="text/html" height="360" width="640" frameborder="0"></iframe>
 </div>
 <p>As the data engineer job has gained more traction, companies such as IBM and <a href="https://searchdatamanagement.techtarget.com/definition/Hadoop">Hadoop</a> vendor Cloudera Inc. have begun offering certifications for data engineering professionals. Some popular data engineer certifications include the following:</p>
 <ul class="default-list"> 
  <li><strong>Certified Data Professional</strong> is offered by the Institute for Certification of computing professionals, or ICCP, as part of its <a href="https://iccp.org/data-professionals.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">general database professional program</a>. Several tracks are offered. Candidates must be members of the ICCP and pay an annual membership fee to take the exam.</li> 
  <li><strong>Cloudera Certified Professional Data Engineer</strong> verifies a candidate's ability to ingest, transform, store and analyze data in Cloudera's data tool environment. Cloudera charges a fee for its <a href="https://www.cloudera.com/about/training/certification/ccp-data-engineer.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">four-hour test</a>. It consists of five to 10 hands-on tasks, and candidates must get a minimum score of 70% to pass. There are no prerequisites, but candidates should have extensive experience.</li> 
  <li><strong>Google Cloud Professional Data Engineer</strong> tests an individual's ability to use machine learning models, ensure data quality and build and design data processing systems. Google charges a fee for the <a href="https://www.dataquest.io/blog/what-is-a-data-engineer/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">two-hour, multiple choice exam</a>. There are no prerequisites, but Google recommends having some experience with Google Cloud Platform.</li> 
 </ul>
 <p>As with many IT certifications, those in data engineering are often based on a specific vendor's product, and the trainings and exams focus on teaching people to use their software.</p>
</section>            
<section class="section main-article-chapter" data-menu-title="How to become a data engineer">
 <h3 class="section-title"><i class="icon" data-icon="1"></i>How to become a data engineer</h3>
 <p>Certifications alone aren't enough to land a data engineering job. Experience is also necessary to be considered for a position. Other ways to break into data engineering include the following:</p>
 <ul class="default-list"> 
  <li><strong>University degrees.</strong> Useful degrees for aspiring data engineers include bachelor's degrees in applied mathematics, computer science, physics or engineering. Also, master's degrees in computer science or computer engineering can help candidates set themselves apart.</li> 
  <li><strong>Online courses.</strong> Inexpensive and free online courses are a good way to learn data engineering skills. There are many useful videos on YouTube, as well as free online courses and resources, such as the following six options: 
   <ol class="default-list"> 
    <li><strong>Codecademy's Learn Python</strong>. <a href="https://www.codecademy.com/learn/learn-python" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Knowledge of Python</a> is essential for data engineers. This course requires no prior knowledge.</li> 
    <li><strong>Coursera's guide to Linux server management and security</strong><strong>. </strong>This four-week course covers the <a href="https://www.coursera.org/learn/linux-server-management-security" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Linux basics</a>.</li> 
    <li><strong>GitHub SQL Cheatsheet</strong><strong>.</strong> This GitHub repository is consistently updated with <a href="https://github.com/enochtangg/quick-SQL-cheatsheet" target="_blank" rel="noopener">SQL query examples</a>.</li> 
    <li><strong>O'Rei</strong><strong>lly data engineering e</strong><strong>-books.</strong> Titles in the <a href="https://www.oreilly.com/data/free/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">big data architecture section</a> cover data engineering topics.</li> 
    <li><strong>Udacity D</strong><strong>ata Engineering Nanodegree</strong><strong>.</strong> Udacity's online learning offerings include a <a href="https://www.udacity.com/course/data-engineer-nanodegree--nd027" target="_blank" rel="noopener">data engineering track</a>.</li> 
   </ol> </li> 
  <li><strong>Project-based learning.</strong> With this more practical approach to learning data engineering skills, the first step is to set a project goal and then determine which skills are necessary to reach it. The project-based approach is a good way to maintain motivation and structure learning.</li> 
 </ul>
</section>   
<section class="section main-article-chapter" data-menu-title="Data engineer vs. data scientist">
 <h3 class="section-title"><i class="icon" data-icon="1"></i>Data engineer vs. data scientist</h3>
 <p>Data engineers and data scientists work together. The data engineers prepare and organize the data that companies have in databases and other formats. They also build data pipelines that make data available to the data scientists. The data scientists use all that data for analytics and other projects that improve business operations and outcomes.</p>
 <p>Data scientists and data engineers differ in their skillsets and focus. Data engineers don't necessarily have a specific focus; they tend to be competent in several areas and well-rounded in their knowledge and skills. By contrast, data scientists often have specialized areas of focus. They are concerned with more <a href="https://searchbusinessanalytics.techtarget.com/feature/Python-exploratory-data-analysis-and-why-its-important">exploratory data analysis</a>. Data scientists tackle new, big-picture problems, while data engineers put the pieces in place to make that possible.</p>
 <figure class="main-article-image full-col" data-img-fullsize="https://cdn.ttgtmedia.com/rms/onlineimages/04_08_20_ESS_2020_4983_business_analytics_key_differences.jpg">
  <img data-src="https://cdn.ttgtmedia.com/rms/onlineimages/04_08_20_ESS_2020_4983_business_analytics_key_differences_mobile.jpg" class="lazy" data-srcset="https://cdn.ttgtmedia.com/rms/onlineimages/04_08_20_ESS_2020_4983_business_analytics_key_differences_mobile.jpg 960w,https://cdn.ttgtmedia.com/rms/onlineimages/04_08_20_ESS_2020_4983_business_analytics_key_differences_desktop.jpg 1280w" alt="how data engineers' and data scientists' skills and responsibilities compare">
  <figcaption>
   <i class="icon pictures" data-icon="z"></i>Data engineers and data scientists have overlapping but different sets of skills and responsibilities on the data management team.
  </figcaption>
  <div class="main-article-image-enlarge">
   <i class="icon" data-icon="w"></i>
  </div>
 </figure>
 <p><em>In addition to data engineers and data scientists, data management and analytics teams contain a variety of roles and specialties. Read more about the skillsets and personnel required to have a </em><a href="https://searchbusinessanalytics.techtarget.com/feature/What-makes-up-a-strong-data-science-team-structure"><em>strong enterprise data science team</em></a><em>.</em></p>
 <div class="extra-info">
  <div class="extra-info-inner">
   <h4>More about data engineers and data scientists</h4> 
   <p>Data scientists and engineers are key parts of any data analytics team. Learn more about the IT pros who work together to make data analytics happen.</p> 
   <ul class="default-list"> 
    <li><a href="https://searchdatamanagement.techtarget.com/feature/USAA-adds-data-engineering-skills-to-speed-data-science-work">USAA adds data engineering skills to speed data science work</a></li> 
    <li><a href="https://searchdatamanagement.techtarget.com/feature/Up-and-coming-data-engineers-complement-entrenched-data-scientists">Up and coming data engineers complement entrenched data scientists</a></li> 
    <li><a href="https://searchbusinessanalytics.techtarget.com/feature/5-ways-enterprises-adapt-to-the-data-scientist-shortage">5 ways enterprises adapt to the data scientist shortage</a></li> 
    <li><a href="https://www.computerweekly.com/feature/How-to-find-a-much-sought-after-data-scientist">How to find a much sought-after data scientist</a></li> 
   </ul>
  </div>
 </div>
</section></section>

<script type="application/ld+json">{"uploadDate":"2021-06-13T10:00Z","name":"Data Engineer vs. Data Scientist vs. Data Analyst: What's the Difference?","duration":"PT3M1S","embedUrl":"https://www.youtube.com/embed/EEu5eZaIHig","thumbnailUrl":"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/EEu5eZaIHig/mqdefault.jpg","description":"Data management roles: Data architect vs. data engineer, others: https://searchdatamanagement.techtarget.com/feature/Data-management-roles-Data-architect-vs-data-engineer-others?utm_source=youtube&utm_medium=description&utm_campaign=062021DATA&utm_content=DATA&Offer=OTHR-youtube_OTHR-video_OTHR-DATA _2021June08_DATA \n\nThere’s a wide variety of data jobs, and they often get mixed up and used interchangeably. Data scientists, data analysts, and data engineers are all necessary positions in organizations. If management conflates roles and hires for the wrong position, business can suffer. But, knowing where they differ is critical for efficient business. Knowing the differences between them these data management roles can benefit organizations -- from hiring, to retention, to general productivity and efficiency of the role. \n\nWhat are some other differentiating factors between these data roles? Share your thoughts in the comments, and be sure to hit that like button. \n\n \nStay up to date on data management: https://searchdatamanagement.techtarget.com \n\nFollow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/@TTBusinessTech \n\nLike us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/TechTargetBusinessTechnology/ \n\n#datascientist #dataanalysts #dataengineeers","@type":"VideoObject","@context":"https://schema.org"}</script><!-- End STRUCTUREDDATA -->

class="rc-RichText"><p>Data engineering is the practice designing and building systems for collecting, storing, and analyzing data at scale. It is a broad field with applications in just about every industry. Organizations have the ability to collect massive amounts of data, and they need the right people and technology to ensure the data is in a highly usable state by the time it reaches the data scientists and analysts.</p><p>In addition to making the lives of data scientists easier, working as a data engineer can give you the opportunity to make a tangible difference in a world where weâll be producing 463 exabytes <i>per day</i> by 2025. Thatâs one and 18 zeros of bytes worth of data. Fields like machine learning and deep learning canât succeed without data engineers to process and channel that data.</p><h2 id="0-what-does-a-data-engineer-do">What does a data engineer do?</h2><p>Data engineers work in a variety of settings to build systems that collect, manage, and convert raw data into usable information for data scientists and business analysts to interpret. Their ultimate goal is to make data accessible so that organizations can use it to evaluate and optimize their performance.</p><p>Listen to some practicing data engineers talk about what they do.</p><div class="rc-ArticleVLPVideoPlayerContainer css-1r3el18"><div class="css-19ww4kk"><div class="rc-VideoPlayerContainer__video-wrapper"><div class="video-overlay video-js css-v4ktz5 cds-113"><span>Course 1 of 13 in the <a data-click-key="articles.article_page.click.vlp_course_s12n_info_link" data-click-value="{"href":"/professional-certificates/ibm-data-engineer","namespace":{"action":"click","app":"articles","component":"vlp_course_s12n_info_link","page":"article_page"},"schema_type":"FRONTEND"}" class="css-9scrul"><div class="cta-container-cds css-1txmzeg"><a data-click-key="articles.article_page.click.vlp_try_course_button" data-click-value="{"href":"?authMode=signup","namespace":{"action":"click","app":"articles","component":"vlp_try_course_button","page":"article_page"},"schema_type":"FRONTEND"}" data-track="true" data-track-app="articles" data-track-page="article_page" data-track-action="click" data-track-component="vlp_try_course_button" data-track-href="?authMode=signup" href="?authMode=signup" to="?authMode=signup" class="cds-170 cds-141 cds-143 try-course try-course-btn css-75ky21 cds-152 cds-button-disableElevation" tabindex="0" aria-disabled="false" data-e2e="try_course_button" data-catchpoint="vlp-try-course-button" role="button"><span class="cds-142 cds-button-label"><span>Enroll for Free</span></span></a></div></div></div></div><p>These are some common tasks you might perform when working with data:</p><p></p><ul><li><p>Acquire datasets that align with business needs</p></li><li><p>Develop algorithms to transform data into useful, actionable information</p></li><li><p>Build, test, and maintain database pipeline architectures</p></li><li><p>Collaborate with management to understand company objectives</p></li><li><p>Create new data validation methods and data analysis tools</p></li><li><p>Ensure compliance with data governance and security policies</p></li></ul><p>Working at smaller companies often means taking on a greater variety of data-related tasks in a generalist role. Some bigger companies have data engineers dedicated to building data pipelines and others focused on managing data warehousesâboth populating warehouses with data and creating table schemas to keep track of where data is stored.</p><div class="rc-ArticleHighlight cds"><div class="css-1jke4yk"><div class="css-ms80i"><div class="css-1kxbypt"><div class="rc-RichText"><h3>Whatâs the difference between a data analyst and a data engineer? </h3><p><b>Data scientists</b> and <b>data analysts</b> analyze data sets to glean knowledge and insights. <b>Data engineers</b> build systems for collecting, validating, and preparing that high-quality data. Data engineers gather and prepare the data and data scientists use the data to promote better business decisions.</p></div></div></div><div class="css-175sjpy"><div class="_1dyqk64"><img alt="Placeholder" src="https://d3njjcbhbojbot.cloudfront.net/api/utilities/v1/imageproxy/https://coursera_assets.s3.amazonaws.com/articles/purple-hash-pattern.svg?auto=format%2Ccompress&dpr=2&blur=200&px=8&w=252&h=152" class="_1nhfz2"/><div class="lazyload-wrapper"><div class="lazyload-placeholder"></div></div></div></div></div></div><h2 id="1-why-pursue-a-career-in-data-engineering">Why pursue a career in data engineering?</h2><p>A career in this field can be both rewarding and challenging. Youâll play an important role in an organizationâs success, providing easier access to data that data scientists, analysts, and decision-makers need to do their jobs. Youâll rely on your programming and problem-solving skills to create scalable solutions.</p><p>As long as there is data to process, data engineers will be in demand. In fact, Dice Insights reported in 2019 that data engineering is a top trending job in the technology industry, beating out computer scientists, web designers, and database architects [<a href="https://insights.dice.com/2019/06/04/data-engineer-remains-top-demand-job/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">1</a>]. LinkedIn listed it as one of its jobs on the rise in 2021 [<a href="https://techhub.dice.com/Dice-Q3-Tech-Job-Report-TY.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer"></a><a href="https://business.linkedin.com/talent-solutions/resources/talent-acquisition/jobs-on-the-rise-us" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">2</a>].Â </p><h3>Data engineer salary</h3><p>Data engineering is also a well-paying career. The average salary in the US is $111,933, with some data engineers earning as much as $164,000 per year, according to Glassdoor (June 2021) [<a href="https://www.glassdoor.com/Salaries/data-engineer-salary-SRCH_KO0,13.htm" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">3</a>]. Compare this with other data roles, such as data analyst ($68,000) or database administrator ($81,444), and you can see that data engineers are compensated well for their skills.</p><h3>Data engineer career path</h3><p>Data engineering isnât always an entry-level role. Instead, many data engineers start off as software engineers or business intelligence analysts. As you advance in your career, you may move into managerial roles or become a data architect, solutions architect, or machine learning engineer.</p><h2 id="2-how-to-become-a-data-engineer">How to become a data engineer</h2><p>With the right set of skills and knowledge, you can launch or advance a rewarding career in data engineering. Many data engineers have a bachelorâs degree in computer science or a related field. By earning a degree, you can build a foundation of knowledge youâll need in this quickly-evolving field. Consider a masterâs degree for the opportunity to advance your career and unlock potentially higher-paying positions.</p><p>Besides earning a degree, there are several other steps you can take to set yourself up for success.</p><h3>1. Develop your data engineering skills.Â </h3><p>Learn the fundamentals of cloud computing, coding skills, and database design as a starting point for a career in data science.</p><p></p><ul><li><p><b>Coding:</b> Proficiency in coding languages is essential to this role, so consider taking courses to learn and practice your skills. Common programming languages includeSQL, NoSQL, Python, Java, R, and Scala.</p></li></ul><ul><li><p><b>Relational and non-relational databases:</b> Databases rank among the most common solutions for data storage. You should be familiar with both relational and non-relational databases, and how they work.</p></li></ul><ul><li><p><b>ETL (extract, transform, and load) systems:</b> ETL is the process by which youâll move data from databases and other sources into a single repository, like a data warehouse. Common ETL tools include Xplenty, Stitch, Alooma, and Talend.</p></li></ul><ul><li><p><b>Data storage:</b> Not all types of data should be stored the same way, especially when it comes to big data. As you design data solutions for a company, youâll want to know when to use a data lake versus a data warehouse, for example.</p></li></ul><ul><li><p><b>Automation and scripting.</b> Automation is a necessary part of working with big data simply because organizations are able to collect so much information. You should be able to write scripts to automate repetitive tasks.</p></li></ul><ul><li><p><b>Machine learning:</b> While machine learning is more the concern of data scientists, it can be helpful to have a grasp of the basic concepts to better understand the needs of data scientists on your team.Â </p></li></ul><ul><li><p><b>Big data tools:</b> Data engineers donât just work with regular data. Theyâre often tasked with managing big data. Tools and technologies are evolving and vary by company, but some popular ones include Hadoop, MongoDB, and Kafka.</p></li></ul><ul><li><p><b>Cloud computing.</b> Youâll need to understand cloud storage and cloud computing as companies increasingly trade physical servers for cloud services. Beginners may consider a course in <a href="https://www.coursera.org/learn/aws-fundamentals-going-cloud-native" target="_self" rel="">Amazon Web Services (AWS)</a> or <a href="https://www.coursera.org/learn/gcp-big-data-ml-fundamentals?specialization=gcp-data-engineering" target="_self" rel="">Google Cloud</a>.</p></li></ul><ul><li><p><b>Data security:</b> While some companies might have dedicated data security teams, many data engineers are still tasked with securely managing and storing data to protect it from loss or theft.</p></li></ul><p><b>Read more:</b> <a href="https://www.coursera.org/articles/cloud-certifications-for-your-it-career" target="_self" rel="">5 Cloud Certifications for Your IT Career in 2021</a></p><h3>2. Get certified.Â </h3><p>A certification can validate your skills to potential employers, and preparing for a certification exam is an excellent way to develop your skills and knowledge. Options include the Associate Big Data Engineer, Cloudera Certified Professional Data Engineer, IBM Certified Data Engineer, or Google Cloud Certified Professional Data Engineer.</p><p>Check out some job listings for roles you may want to apply for. If you notice a particular certification is frequently listed as required or recommended, that might be a good place to start.</p><div class="rc-ArticleEntityCard css-1wl4stb"><div class="cds-1 css-0 cds-2"><div class="cds-1 css-1one93i cds-3 cds-grid-item cds-48 cds-53"><div class="css-talvtv"><div class="_sin5df"><img alt="Placeholder" src="https://d3njjcbhbojbot.cloudfront.net/api/utilities/v1/imageproxy/https://d15cw65ipctsrr.cloudfront.net/1b/67a18a33de439c974816ebfd42e7b2/unnamed.png?auto=format%2Ccompress&dpr=2&blur=200&px=8&w=124&h=124" class="_1nhfz2"/><div class="lazyload-wrapper"><div class="lazyload-placeholder"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="cds-1 css-0 cds-3 cds-grid-item cds-48 cds-59"><p class="cds-111 css-mdmmlk cds-113">IBM Data Engineering</p><p class="cds-111 css-f4rrn2 cds-113">IBM</p><div class="cds-1 css-0 cds-2"><div class="cds-1 css-nylfmx cds-3 cds-grid-item cds-48 cds-56"><span class="cds-111 css-qmuuhx cds-113">PROFESSIONAL CERTIFICATE</span></div><div class="cds-1 css-bhmogh cds-3 cds-grid-item cds-48 cds-56"><div><a data-click-key="articles.article_page.click.article_entity_card_cta" data-click-value="{"ctaHref":"/professional-certificates/ibm-data-engineer","href":"/professional-certificates/ibm-data-engineer","label":"PROFESSIONAL CERTIFICATE","namespace":{"action":"click","app":"articles","component":"article_entity_card_cta","page":"article_page"},"schema_type":"FRONTEND"}" data-track="true" data-track-app="articles" data-track-page="article_page" data-track-action="click" data-track-component="article_entity_card_cta" data-track-href="/professional-certificates/ibm-data-engineer" href="/professional-certificates/ibm-data-engineer" to="/professional-certificates/ibm-data-engineer" class="cds-170 cds-141 cds-143 css-1dqph2j cds-152 cds-button-disableElevation" tabindex="0" aria-disabled="false" role="button"><span class="cds-142 cds-button-label">Learn More</span></a></div></div></div></div></div></div><h3>3. Build a portfolio of data engineering projects.Â </h3><p>A portfolio is often a key component in a job search, as it shows recruiters, hiring managers, and potential employers what you can do. </p><p>You can add data engineering projects you've completed independently or as part of coursework to a portfolio website (using a service like Wix or Squarespace). Alternately, post your work to the Projects section of your LinkedIn profile or to a site like GitHubâboth free alternatives to a standalone portfolio site. </p><p>Brush up on your big data skills with a portfolio-ready Guided Project that you can complete in under two hours. Here are some options to get you startedâno software downloads required:</p><p></p><ul><li><p><a href="https://www.coursera.org/projects/nosql-database-with-mongodb-and-compass" target="_self" rel="">Create Your First NoSQL Database with MongoDB and Compass</a></p></li><li><p><a href="https://www.coursera.org/projects/database-design-with-sql-server-management-studio" target="_self" rel="">Database Design with SQL Server Management Studio (SSMS)</a> </p></li><li><p><a href="https://www.coursera.org/projects/database-creation-and-modeling-using-mysql-workbench" target="_self" rel="">Database Creation and Modeling using MYSQL Workbench</a></p></li></ul><p><b>Read more:</b> <a href="https://www.coursera.org/articles/how-to-build-a-data-analyst-portfolio" target="_self" rel="">How to Build a Data Analyst Portfolio: Tips for Success</a></p><h3>4. Start with an entry-level position.Â </h3><p>Many data engineers start off in entry-level roles, such as business intelligence analyst or database administrator. As you gain experience, you can pick up new skills and qualify for more advanced roles.Â See an example of a possible learning journey with this <a href="https://www.coursera.org/learning-paths/data-engineering" target="_self" rel="">Data Engineering Career Learning Path from Coursera</a>.</p><div class="rc-ArticleHighlight cds"><div class="css-1jke4yk"><div class="css-ms80i"><div class="css-1kxbypt"><div class="rc-RichText"><h3>Do I need a degree to become a data engineer?</h3><p>Itâs not necessary to have a degree to become a data engineer, though some companies might prefer candidates with at least a bachelorâs degree. If youâre interested in a career in data engineering and plan to pursue a degree, consider majoring in computer science, software engineering, data science, or information systems.Â </p><p>Some bachelorâs degree programs offer a concentration in data engineering. The <a href="https://www.coursera.org/degrees/bachelor-of-science-computer-science-london" target="_self" rel="">Bachelor of Science in Computer Science from the University of London</a>, for example, features an optional module in databases and advanced data techniques.</p></div></div></div><div class="css-175sjpy"><div class="_1dyqk64"><img alt="Placeholder" src="https://d3njjcbhbojbot.cloudfront.net/api/utilities/v1/imageproxy/https://coursera_assets.s3.amazonaws.com/articles/purple-hash-pattern.svg?auto=format%2Ccompress&dpr=2&blur=200&px=8&w=252&h=152" class="_1nhfz2"/><div class="lazyload-wrapper"><div class="lazyload-placeholder"></div></div></div></div></div></div><h2 id="3-next-steps">Next steps</h2><p>Whether youâre just getting started or looking to pivot to a new career, start building job-ready skills for roles in data with the <a href="https://www.coursera.org/professional-certificates/google-data-analytics" target="_self" rel="">Google Data Analytics</a>, <a href="https://www.coursera.org/professional-certificates/ibm-data-science" target="_self" rel="">IBM Data Science</a>, or <a href="https://www.coursera.org/professional-certificates/ibm-data-engineer" target="_self" rel="">IBM Data Engineering</a> Professional Certificates. </p><figure><img src="https://images.ctfassets.net/wp1lcwdav1p1/2x3iyksaSCVSXTAKcUYkhN/51e17db82241ad258fe8a47f88bfda33/download4.jpeg?w=1500&q=60" alt="White text on a blue background that reads "Build in-demand skills with the IBM Data Engineering Professional Certificate. engineering is the practice designing and building systems for collecting, storing, and analyzing data at scale. It is a broad field with applications in just about every industry. Organizations have the ability to collect massive amounts of data, and they need the right people and technology to ensure the data is in a highly usable state by the time it reaches the data scientists and analysts.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"In addition to making the lives of data scientists easier, working as a data engineer can give you the opportunity to make a tangible difference in a world where weâll be producing 463 exabytes ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"per day","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" by 2025. Fields like machine learning and deep learning canât succeed without data engineers to process and channel that data.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"heading-2","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"What does a data engineer do?","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Data engineers work in a variety of settings to build systems that collect, manage, and convert raw data into usable information for data scientists and business analysts to interpret. Their ultimate goal is to make data accessible so that organizations can use it to evaluate and optimize their performance.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Listen to some practicing data engineers talk about what they Motivation

class=""><article><section class="pt-8 bg-gradient-to-t from-c_grad_seo_resources-end to-c_grad_seo_resources-start"><div class="container px-2 md:px-4"><h1 class="mb-2 text-4xl md:text-h1">Data Engineering: A Guide to the Who, What, and How</h1><div class="mb-5"></div><nav aria-label="Breadcrumb" class="Breadcrumbs-module--BreadcrumbWrapper--fJtks"><ul class="Breadcrumbs-module--BreadcrumbList--Y8_QB"><li class="Breadcrumbs-module--BreadcrumbItem--2V7y3"><a class="Breadcrumbs-module--BreadcrumbLink--TKr9-" href="/knowledge-center/">Knowledge class="Breadcrumbs-module--BreadcrumbLink--TKr9-">Data Engineering: A Guide to the Who, Wh…</span></li></ul></nav></div></section><section class="container px-2 md:px-4 text-c_slate pageWithSideBar"><div class="mb-2 p-3 shadow-lg border border-c_light_grey relative z-10 hidden md:block md:w-52 md:float-right md:ml-2"><h5>Related articles</h5><ul><li class="mb-2"><a class="hover:text-c_primary hover:underline text-base" href="/resources/service-oriented-architecture/">What is Service-oriented Architecture (SOA)?</a></li><li class="mb-2"><a class="hover:text-c_primary hover:underline text-base" href="/resources/containerization-in-the-cloud/">Containerization in the Cloud</a></li><li class="mb-2"><a class="hover:text-c_primary hover:underline text-base" href="/resources/what-is-infrastructure-as-code/">What is Infrastructure as Code (IaC)?</a></li><li class="mb-2"><a class="hover:text-c_primary hover:underline text-base" href="/resources/what-is-devops/">DevOps: Fastest Path to the Future of Development</a></li><li class="mb-2"><a class="hover:text-c_primary hover:underline text-base" href="/resources/cloud-orchestration/">How Cloud Orchestration Solves Automation Growing Pains</a></li></ul></div><p class="">In the modern world, it is tough to think of any industry that has not been revolutionized by data science. Although many may not understand the intricacies of the data science discipline, they have enough exposure to know that data science is a growing field. People open their email to find personalized discounts, turn to Siri for immediate answers to their questions, and depend on their bank to identify and mitigate any potential fraud activity. </p><p class="">While we are enjoying the fruits of data science’s labor, there are other players working diligently behind the scenes. These employees are responsible for creating the <a href="/resources/what-is-a-data-pipeline/">data pipelines</a> and warehouses that enable data scientists to write and optimize algorithms in order to enhance our everyday lives.</p><p class="">Who are these supporting actors? Data engineers.</p><h2 class="">What is data engineering?</h2><p class="">Conclusions drawn from big datasets are only as valuable as its <a href="/resources/what-is-data-integrity/">data integrity</a>. Without an architecture that can structure and format growing and changing datasets, <a href="/resources/what-is-data-science/">data scientists</a> are unable to make accurate predictions. This is where data engineering comes into play.</p><p class="">Data Engineering is the act of collecting, translating, and validating data for analysis. In particular, data engineers build data warehouses to empower data-driven decisions. Data engineering lays the foundation for real-world data science application. Working harmoniously, data engineers and data scientists can deliver consistently valuable insights.</p><h2 class="">Required data engineering skills and responsibilities</h2><p class="">Data engineering requires a broad set of skills ranging from programming to database design and system architecture. Here are just a few:</p><ul><li>Extensive experience with data processing and ETL/ELT techniques</li><li>Knowledge of Python, SQL, and Linux</li><li>A deep understanding of cluster management, data visualization, batch processing, and machine learning</li><li>Aptitude for developing a foundational understanding of company data</li><li>Proven ability to institute appropriate architecture and establish sustainable pipeline management</li><li>Proficiency in report and dashboard creation</li></ul><p class="">Data engineers are focused on providing the right kind of data at the right time. A good data engineer will anticipate data scientists’ questions and how they might want to present data. Data engineers ensure that the most pertinent data is reliable, transformed, and ready to use. This is a difficult feat, as most organizations rarely gather clean raw data.</p><p class="">To work their magic, most data engineers must be proficient in Python, SQL, and Linux. Data engineers may also need skills in cluster management, data visualization, batch processing, and machine learning. Data engineers use these processing techniques to massage data into a format that facilitates hundreds of queries.</p><p class="">While data engineers may not be directly involved in data analysis, they must have a baseline understanding of company data to set up appropriate architecture. Creating the best system architecture depends on a data engineer’s ability to <a href="/resources/create-real-time-data-pipelines/">shape and maintain data pipelines</a>. Experienced data engineers might blend multiple <a href="/resources/what-is-data-processing/">big data processing technologies</a> to meet a company’s overarching data needs.</p><aside     }</style></noscript></div></aside><h2 class="">Data engineer vs. data scientist: What’s the difference?</h2><p class="">Although data engineers and data scientists are tied together closely when working in a company, these two roles differ greatly in skillset and job function. </p><p class="">Data engineers concentrate on production readiness. They prepare and manage data for data scientists’ use. Overall, data engineers care most about how company data is presented, how it scales, how secure it is, and how easy it is to change data pipelines based on new information.</p><p class="">As a result, data engineers typically have an extensive knowledge of data storage and transformation tools. With a solid foundation in ETL design, <a href="/resources/what-is-data-modeling/">data modeling</a>, relational and non-relational database design, and query execution, data engineers have the ability to choose the technique most suitable to handle each dataset.</p><p class="">Data scientists, on the other hand, <a href="/resources/what-is-data-mining/">mine prepared data</a> for valuable insights. Using data formatted by data engineers, data scientists develop algorithms that surface underlying issues or business opportunities. As you might expect, data scientists have familiarity with analytics programming languages like SQL and Python.</p><p class="">Data scientists work closely with data engineers to adjust their algorithms. Data engineers can point out data limitations to help data scientists better account for variables and <a href="/resources/what-is-data-analytics/">draw more meaningful conclusions</a>.</p><h2 class="">Data engineering tools and solutions for your business</h2><p class="">Clearly data engineers have a comprehensive idea of how data can be stored, processed, and delivered. But how do they begin to put this knowledge to use?</p><p class="">First, data engineers construct a <a href="/resources/what-is-data-warehouse/">data warehouse</a>. The tried and true process that data engineers use is called <a href="/resources/what-is-etl/">ETL — Extract, Transform, Load</a>. The best ETL tools often include automated alerts when there are errors in a pipeline and permit the use of open-source code.</p><p class="">Recently, some data engineers have switched two steps in the ETL process, forming a new, <a href="/resources/what-is-elt/">“ELT” method.</a> When loading data occurs before data transformation, all data is accessible at any time. With the ever-increasing data pool and the availability of cloud storage, this method is becoming very popular. For this reason, data engineering tools that support <a href="/resources/elt-vs-etl/">ETL or ELT</a> processes are critical. ELT tools should be cloud-based solutions and offer end-to-end support to stay abreast of new web-based data streams and afford extreme flexibility.</p><h2 class="">The cloud and the future of data engineering</h2><p class="">The cloud has most certainly led to the need for data engineering. Agile businesses require the efficiency, organization, and speed that comes with proper data engineering. </p><p class="">In the future, data engineering will only become more relevant. Companies are beginning to understand the extreme advantage of big data and are investing in data science initiatives. Data engineering will follow suit, as data science relies on sustainable, standardized data.</p><p class="">In fact, the data science field is starting to establish sub-disciplines, like: <a href="/resources/what-is-data-visualization/">visualization</a>, <a href="/resources/what-is-machine-learning/">machine learning</a>, and data storytelling. <a href="/resources/what-is-artificial-intelligence/">Artificial intelligence and neural networks</a> are becoming especially popular in fields like healthcare, climate change, and finance. All of these strategies necessitate the clean, transformed data that data engineers provide.</p><p class="">Lastly, many people are fearful of <a href="/resources/data-privacy/">data ethics and privacy</a>. With so much data available, companies will be placing an increased emphasis on strict security measures. Information security is a major component of data engineering. Individuals, companies, and governments will all need to rely on competent <a href="/resources/what-is-data-governance/">data engineers to keep their data safe</a>.</p><h2 class="">Getting started with data engineering</h2><p class="">Data analysis is critically important in this day and age. Companies once struggling to keep up with the vast amounts of data they collect have benefited greatly from data engineering. With innovative data engineering, data scientists have the power to offer invaluable insights that could disrupt entire industries.</p><p class="">Without the right software and structure, data scientists would yield different results from the same research question, end users could experience outages, or pipelines may malfunction causing data scientists to spend hours on repetitive, manual deep dives. Companies need a cloud-based ETL/ELT solution with ample data storage and self-service capabilities.</p><p class=""><a href="/products/data-fabric/">Talend Data Fabric</a> offers a single suite of apps that store, govern, transform, and share data — making data monitoring and ETL/ELT management a breeze. Talend Data Fabric is simple for data engineers to use, and can scale with advanced functionality as companies invest in their data teams. Get ready to disrupt your industry today with <a href="/free-trial/">Talend Data Fabric</a>.</p></section><section class="fullWidth-module--fullWidthModule--2iA47 fullWidth-module--isFramed--3s6qM fullWidth-module--frameColorWhite--10BdS textShadeLight textAlignCenter spacingBottomM spacingTopM bgGradientBlogGradient bgPositionLeft bgSizeContain frameColorWhite"><div class="fullWidth-module--gridWrapper--3j0hP fullWidth-module--isFramed--3s6qM fullWidth-module--frameWrapper--3xCzZ bgGradientBlogGradient spacingTopM spacingBottomM"><div class="fullWidth-module--container--x434C copyWidth100 copyContainer"><div class="heading"><h2>Ready to get started with Talend?</h2><p></p></div></div><div class="fullWidth-module--container--x434C"><div class="fullWidth-module--ctaSection--NjGgs"><a class="btn btnSecondary  cta-module--btn--2mmlX cta-module--btnSecondary--1pipX" href="/contact-sales/">Contact sales</a></div></div><div class="bgImage fullWidth-module--bgWrapper--3Iq8d gbi--1534928984-1fVhA3QyffYMxKh2PY3L4B" style="background-position:left;background-repeat:no-repeat;background-size:contain;position:absolute;z-index:1;opacity:0.99"><style>

				<script type="text/javascript">
			window.flatStyles = window.flatStyles || ''

			window.lightspeedOptimizeStylesheet = function () {
				const currentStylesheet = document.querySelector( '.tcb-lightspeed-style:not([data-ls-optimized])' )

				if ( currentStylesheet ) {
					try {
						if ( currentStylesheet.sheet && currentStylesheet.sheet.cssRules ) {
							if ( window.flatStyles ) {
								if ( this.optimizing ) {
									setTimeout( window.lightspeedOptimizeStylesheet.bind( this ), 24 )
								} else {
									this.optimizing = true;

									let rulesIndex = 0;

									while ( rulesIndex < currentStylesheet.sheet.cssRules.length ) {
										const rule = currentStylesheet.sheet.cssRules[ rulesIndex ]
										/* remove rules that already exist in the page */
										if ( rule.type === CSSRule.STYLE_RULE && window.flatStyles.includes( `${rule.selectorText}{` ) ) {
											currentStylesheet.sheet.deleteRule( rulesIndex )
										} else {
											rulesIndex ++
										}
									}
									/* optimize, mark it such, move to the next file, append the styles we have until now */
									currentStylesheet.setAttribute( 'data-ls-optimized', '1' )

									window.flatStyles += currentStylesheet.innerHTML

									this.optimizing = false
								}
							} else {
								window.flatStyles = currentStylesheet.innerHTML
								currentStylesheet.setAttribute( 'data-ls-optimized', '1' )
							}
						}
					} catch ( error ) {
						console.warn( error )
					}

					if ( currentStylesheet.parentElement.tagName !== 'HEAD' ) {
						/* always make sure that those styles end up in the head */
						document.head.prepend( currentStylesheet )
					}
				}
			}

			window.lightspeedOptimizeFlat = function ( styleSheetElement ) {
				if ( document.querySelectorAll( 'link[href*="thrive_flat.css"]' ).length > 1 ) {
					/* disable this flat if we already have one */
					styleSheetElement.setAttribute( 'disabled', true )
				} else {
					/* if this is the first one, make sure he's in head */
					if ( styleSheetElement.parentElement.tagName !== 'HEAD' ) {
						document.head.append( styleSheetElement )
					}
				}
			}
		</script>

	<script>
		console.log("testing testing");
		
		/************* Helper functions ******************/
		function isInArray(value, array) {
		  return array.indexOf(value) > -1;
		}
		function getHostFromUrl(url) {
			var a=document.createElement('a');
			a.href=url;
			return a.hostname;
		}
		function getUrlVar(key){
			var result = new RegExp(key + "=([^&]*)", "i").exec(window.location.search); 
			return result && unescape(result[1]) || ""; 
		}
		/************* End of Helper Functions ******************/
		
		
		/******************** Cookie helper functions ************************/
		function checkCookieExists(cookie_name) {
			return document.cookie.indexOf(cookie_name + '=') !== -1;
		}
		function setCookie(name,value,domain,days) {
			var expires = "";
			if (days) {
				var date = new Date();
				date.setTime(date.getTime() + (days*24*60*60*1000));
				expires = "; expires=" + date.toUTCString();
			}
			document.cookie = name + "=" + (value || "")  + expires +  ";domain=" + domain + "; path=/";
		}
		/******************** End Of Cookie helper functions ******************/
		
		function setRefererUrlCookie() {
			var cookie_domain = '.www.dataquest.io'
			var internal_hosts =  ['dq-staging.t79ae38x-liquidwebsites.com', 'www.dataquest.io', ]

			/* Set Landing page cookie if it doesnot exist */
			if (!checkCookieExists('dataquest-cac-landing-page')) {
				setCookie('dataquest-cac-landing-page', window.location.pathname, cookie_domain, 7)
			}
			
			var referrer = document.referrer

			if (window.console && window.console.log && (typeof window.console.log === "function")) {
				window.console.log('referrer', referrer);
			} 
			
			if (!referrer) {
				return
			}
			host = getHostFromUrl(referrer)
			
			/* If referrer is not coming from dataquest, set it in cookie and override landing_page cookie */
			if (!isInArray(host, internal_hosts)) {
				setCookie('dataquest-cac-referer-url', referrer, cookie_domain, 365)
				setCookie('dataquest-cac-landing-page', window.location.pathname, cookie_domain, 365)
			}
		}

		function setUTMCodesCookies() {
			var utm_codes = ['utm_source','utm_campaign','utm_content','utm_term','utm_medium']
			var cookie_prefix = 'dataquest-cac-'
			var cookie_domain = '.www.dataquest.io'
			
			for (code in utm_codes) {
				var utm_code = utm_codes[code]
				var code_value = getUrlVar(utm_code)
				var cookie_name = cookie_prefix + utm_code.replace('_', '-')
				
				if (code_value) {
					setCookie(cookie_name, code_value, cookie_domain, 365)
				}
			}
		}
									
		
		function setLandingPageLastTouchCookie() {
			var cookie_domain = '.www.dataquest.io'
			setCookie('dataquest-cac-landing-page-last-touch', window.location.pathname, cookie_domain, 365)

		}
		
		setUTMCodesCookies()
		setRefererUrlCookie()
		setLandingPageLastTouchCookie()

	</script>
	<script type="text/javascript" id="refersion-tracking">
	  (function(d) {
        if (localStorage.getItem("rfsn_aid") && localStorage.getItem("rfsn_cs") && localStorage.getItem("rfsn_cs") !== "b5b961" && localStorage.getItem("rfsn_aid") !== "5396695") {
          function setToken() {
			  var rfsnAffiliateToken = localStorage.getItem("rfsn_aid") + "." + localStorage.getItem("rfsn_cs");
			  var links = Array.from(document.querySelectorAll("a")).filter(el => el.href.indexOf("/payment") !== -1);
			  for (var i=0; i<links.length; i++) {
				var link = links[i]
				if (link.href.indexOf("app.dataquest") !== -1) {
				  var linkDelimiter = link.href.indexOf("?") === -1 ? "?" : "&"
				  link.href = link.href + linkDelimiter + "rfsn=" + rfsnAffiliateToken
				}
			  }
		  }
		  setToken();
		  d.addEventListener("DOMContentLoaded", setToken);
        }
	  })(document);
	</script>
	<script type="text/javascript" id="skip-onboarding">
	  (function(d) {
        var pathname = d.location.pathname.replace(/^[/]|[/]$/g, "").replace("/", "-");
        var type = pathname.startsWith("course") ? "?course=" : pathname.startsWith("path") ? "?path=" : null;
		function setUrl() {
		  var tags = d.getElementsByTagName("iframe");

		  if (type) {
			pathname = pathname.replace("course-", "").replace("path-", "");
			if (pathname === "introduction-to-data-analysis-in-r")
				pathname = "intro-to-r-rewrite"
			var i;
			for (i = 0; i < tags.length; i++) {
			  var tag = tags[i];
			  if (tag.src.indexOf("app.dataquest.io/signup") !== -1 && tag.src.indexOf("iframe") !== -1) {
				var query = [];
				if (tag.src.indexOf("?") !== -1) {
				  query = tag.src.substring(tag.src.indexOf("?"), tag.src.indexOf("#iframe")).split("&");
				}
				var newSrc = "https://app.dataquest.io/signup" + type + pathname;
				for (j = 0; j < query.length; j++) {
				  if (!query[j].startsWith("course=") && !query[j].startsWith("path=")) {
					  newSrc += "&" + query[j];
				  }
				}
				tag.src = newSrc + "#iframe";
			  }
			}
		  }
		};
		if (type) {
			d.addEventListener("DOMContentLoaded", setUrl);
		}
	  })(document);
	</script>

			.single-post h2 {font-size: 42px; font-weight: 600;}
.single-post h3 {font-size: 32px; font-weight: 600;}
.single-post h4 {font-size: 28px; font-weight: 600;}
.single-post h5 {font-size: 26px; font-weight: 600;}
.single-post h6 {font-size: 24px; font-weight: 600;}



ul li {list-style-position: outside;}


.kg-card-markdown {line-height: 1.7em;}


.blue-highlight { background: linear-gradient(to bottom, white 50%, #d1e5fa 0%);
  }

.post-template-default h2 { padding-top: 30px;}

.path-box h3 {font-size: 17px!important; font-weight: 900; margin: 0px 0px 5px 0px; line-height: 1em}

.path-box p {line-height: 1.6em; font-size: 14px;}

.path-box a {text-decoration: none!important; }

.path-box-button {height: 50px;}

a .path-box-button-text p  {text-transform: uppercase!important; letter-spacing: 1px; color: #ffffff!important; margin-top: 0px; padding-top: 4px;}



:not(pre) > code[class*="language-"], pre[class*="language-"] {background-color: #000000; border-radius: 3px;}

pre[class*="language-"] {margin: 20px 0px!important; }

p code {
background-color: #e5eff5;
padding: 1px 3px;
border-radius: 3px;
color: #000000;}

pre {background: #000000; margin-top: -10px;}
pre code {padding: 0px; color: #ffffff; background: #000000;}

code[class*="language-"], pre[class*="language-"] { margin-bottom: 20px; margin-top: -10px;}


.single-post table {width: 85%; margin: 30px auto; }

.single-post table th {background-color: #f4f8fb; /*text-transform: lowercase;*/ color: #232a3d!important;}

.single-post table td, article table th {border: 1px solid #e3ecf3; padding: 3px}


div table{
    overflow-x:auto;
}


.tvo-set12-template.tve_teal .tvo-testimonial-quote {color: #4976ea!important;}

.tvo-set12-template.tve_teal .tvo-testimonial-name {color: #4976ea!important;}

.directory-coursebox h3 {font-size: 20px; padding-bottom: 18px; }

.directory-coursebox p {margin-top: -20px; margin-bottom: 14px!important; }

.directory-coursebox div.thrv_wrapper.thrv-button {padding-top: 7px;}

.directory-course-label p {margin: 4px 0px; display: none;}

@media only screen and (max-width: 767px){.center-on-mobile {text-align: center;}}



@media only screen and (max-width: 769px) {
	.directory-coursebox .tcb--cols--2, .directory-coursebox .tcb--cols--2 p { text-align: center!important; }}

@media only screen and (max-width: 769px) {
	.directory-coursebox .tcb--cols--2 .directory-course-label p { margin-top: -20px;}}

@media only screen and (max-width: 769px) {
	.directory-coursebox .tcb--cols--2 .thrv-button a { margin-top: -20px;}}

.directory-coursebox .tcb-button-texts {padding: 0px 20px;}

@media only screen and (max-width: 767px){.thrv_wrapper.thrv-columns.directory-course-columns {margin-top: -40px;}}

.path-box-button-text p { font-weight: 700;}

.course-box-course-info p { font-weight: 700; font-size: 14px}

.course-box h2 {font-size: 22px;}

.course-box p {font-size: 13px;}

.course-box a {text-decoration: none!important;}

.scn.aut {
    box-shadow: none;
    background: #ffffff;
    border-radius: 5px;
    border: 2px solid #d4d4d4;
    margin-bottom: 10px;
}


.tvo-set12-template.tvo-testimonials-display-single .tvo-testimonial-quote { font-size: 168px!important; margin-left: -10px;}

.tvo-set12-template.tvo-testimonials-display-single p {margin-top: -40px;}

.tvo-testimonial-image-cover .tvo-testimonial-real-border {display: block!important;}


.tvo-testimonial-info svg {display: none; }


.tvo-set12-template.tvo-testimonials-display-single .tvo-testimonial-quote:before, .tvo-set12-template.tvo-testimonials-display-single .tvo-testimonial-quote:after {display: none;}



.gmt-edd-slack-alert-success {border: 1px solid #000000; padding: 20px; text-align: center;}







.ctb {border: none;}
.ctb h5  {display: none;}






.thrv_countdown_timer .tve_t_part .t-digits {color: #ffffff!important; margin: 0px!important;}

.tve-leads-ribbon .thrv_countdown_timer .tve_t_part .t-digits {color: #ffffff!important; margin: 0px!important; font-size: 70%!important; margin-bottom: -8px!important; letter-spacing: 1;}




.tve_flt .tve_contents_table .tve_ct_title {text-align: left; display: block; margin: 0px ; padding: 0px 0px 10px; font-weight: bold; font-size: 24px;}

.tve-leads-ribbon.tve-leads-triggered {
    z-index: 100;
}



.tve-ult-bar {z-index: 9;}


body svg.tcb-icon path {
    fill: none !important;
}


.lesson-app-preview .tve-content-box-background {background-image:linear-gradient(rgb(35 42 61 / 9%), rgb(35, 42, 61)),url(https://www.dataquest.io/wp-content/uploads/lesson_pages/Visualizing-Geographic-Data.png) !important;}



.skillpath-course-box ul li {margin-left: 0px;}


.dq-sign-up {width: 100%!important;}

	<div class="tve-cb"><div class="thrv_wrapper thrv_text_element" style="" data-css="tve-u-1705cdb4152"><h1 class="" style="color: var(--tcb-skin-color-23)  !important; --tcb-applied-color:var$(--tcb-skin-color-23)  !important;"><span class="fr-marker" data-id="0" data-type="true" style="display: none; line-height: 0;"></span><span class="thrive-shortcode-content" data-attr-link="0" data-attr-rel="0" data-attr-target="0" data-extra_key="" data-option-inline="1" data-shortcode="tcb_post_title" data-shortcode-name="Post title" data-attr-static-link="{"className":"tve-dynamic-link tve-froala","class":"tve-dynamic-link tve-froala","href":"((tcb_post_the_permalink))","data-shortcode-id":"33122","data-dynamic-link":"tcb_post_the_permalink","data-custom-shortcode":"","dynamic-postlink":"tcb_post_the_permalink","target":"_blank"}" data-css="tve-u-1798752e416"><a class="tve-dynamic-link tve-froala" class="tve-dynamic-link tve-froala" href="https://www.dataquest.io/blog/what-is-a-data-engineer/" data-shortcode-id="33122" data-dynamic-link="tcb_post_the_permalink" data-custom-shortcode="" dynamic-postlink="tcb_post_the_permalink" target="_blank">What is a Data Engineer?</a></span><span class="fr-marker" data-id="0" data-type="false" style="display: none; line-height: 0;"></span></h1></div><div class="thrv_wrapper thrv-divider" data-style-d="tve_sep-1" data-thickness-d="1" data-color-d="rgb(242, 243, 247)" data-css="tve-u-1798748f771">
	<hr class="tve_sep tve_sep-1" style="">
</div><div class="thrv_wrapper thrv_text_element" data-css="tve-u-1798747d354" style=""><div class="tcb-plain-text" data-css="tve-u-17981574b82" style="color: var(--tcb-color-13)  !important; --tcb-applied-color:var$(--tcb-color-13)  !important;"><em>Published: <span class="thrive-shortcode-content" data-attr-date-format="F j, Y" data-attr-date-format-select="F j, Y" data-attr-show-time="0" data-attr-time-format="" data-attr-time-format-select="g:i a" data-attr-type="published" data-extra_key="" data-option-inline="1" data-shortcode="tcb_post_published_date" data-shortcode-name="Post date" style="" data-css="tve-u-17981571b56">January 25, 2017 </span></em></div></div><div class="thrv_wrapper thrv-divider" data-style-d="tve_sep-1" data-thickness-d="1" data-color-d="rgb(242, 243, 247)" data-css="tve-u-1798748a270">
	<hr class="tve_sep tve_sep-1" style="">
</div><section class="tcb-post-content tcb-shortcode thrv_wrapper" data-css="tve-u-16ec5d248bb"><div id="tve_flt" class="tve_flt tcb-style-wrap"><div id="tve_editor" class="tve_shortcode_editor tar-main-content" data-post-id="1989"><div class="thrv_wrapper tve_wp_shortcode"><div class="tve_shortcode_raw" style="display: none"></div><div class="tve_shortcode_rendered"><div class="kg-card-markdown">
<p>From helping <a href="https://www.wired.com/2017/01/human-problem-blocking-path-self-driving-cars/">cars drive themselves</a> to helping <a href="https://www.npr.org/sections/alltechconsidered/2016/05/18/477819617/facebooks-facial-recognition-software-is-different-from-the-fbis-heres-why">Facebook tag you in photos</a>, data science has attracted a lot of buzz recently.  Data scientists have become <a href="https://readwrite.com/2014/07/21/data-scientist-income-skills-jobs/">extremely sought after</a>, and for good reason — a skilled data scientist can add incredible value to a business. But what about data engineers? Who are they, and what do they do?</p>
<p>A data scientist is only as good as the data they have access to. Most companies store their data in variety of formats across databases and text files. This is where data engineers come in — they build pipelines that transform that data into formats that data scientists can use. Data engineers are just as important as data scientists, but tend to be less visible because they tend to be further from the end product of the analysis.</p>
<p>A good analogy is a race car builder vs a race car driver.  The driver gets the excitement of speeding along a track, and thrill of victory in front of a crowd.  But the builder gets the joy of tuning engines, experimenting with different exhaust setups, and creating a powerful, robust, machine.  If you’re the type of person that likes building and tweaking systems, data engineering might be right for you.  In this post, we’ll explore the day to day of a data engineer, and discuss the skills required for the role.</p>
<h2 id="thedataengineerrole">The Data Engineer Role</h2>
<p>The data science field is incredibly broad, encompassing everything from cleaning data to deploying predictive models.  However, it’s rare for any single data scientist to be working across the spectrum day to day.  Data scientists usually focus on a few areas, and are complemented by a team of other scientists and analysts.</p>
<p>Data engineering is also a broad field, but any individual data engineer doesn’t need to know the whole spectrum of skills.  In this section, we’ll sketch the broad outlines of data engineering, then walk through more specific descriptions that illustrate specific data engineering roles.</p>
<p>A data engineer transforms data into a useful format for analysis.  Imagine that you’re a data engineer working on a simple competitor to Uber called Rebu.  Your users have an app on their device through which they access your service.  They request a ride to a destination through your app, which gets routed to a driver, who then picks them up and drops them off.  After the ride, they’re charged, and have the option to rate their driver.</p>
<p>In order to maintain a service like this, you need:</p>
<ul>
<li>A mobile app for users</li>
<li>A mobile app for drivers</li>
<li>A server that can pass requests from users to drivers, and handle other details like updating payment information</li>
</ul>
<p>Here’s a diagram showing the communication:</p>
<p><img src="/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/ditaa_diagram_1-3.png" alt="ditaa_diagram_1-3"></p>
<p>As you may expect, this kind of system will generate huge amounts of data.  You’ll have a few different data stores:</p>
<ul>
<li>The database that backs your main app.  This contains user and driver information.</li>
<li>Server analytics logs
<ul>
<li>Server access logs.  These contain one line per request made to the server from the app.</li>
<li>Server error logs.  These contain all the server-side errors generated by your app.</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>App analytics logs
<ul>
<li>App event logs.  These contain information about what actions users and drivers took in the app.  For example, you’d log when they clicked a button or updated their payment information.</li>
<li>App error logs.  These contain information about errors in the app.</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>Ride database.  This contains information about a single ride for user/driver pair, and contains status information on the ride.</li>
<li>Customer service database.  This contains information about customer interactions by customer service agents.  It can include voice transcripts and email logs.</li>
</ul>
<p>Here’s an updated diagram showing the data sources:</p>
<p><img src="/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/ditaa_diagram_2-2.png" alt="ditaa_diagram_2-2"></p>
<p>Let’s say a data scientist wants to analyze a user’s action history with your service, and see what actions correlate with users who spend more.  In order to enable them to create this, you’ll need to combine information from the server access logs and the app event logs.  You’ll need to:</p>
<ul>
<li>Gather app analytics logs from user devices regularly</li>
<li>Combine the app analytics logs with any server log entries that reference the user</li>
<li>Create an API endpoint that returns the event history of any user</li>
</ul>
<p>In order to solve this, you’ll need to create a pipeline that can ingest mobile app logs and server logs in real-time, parse them, and attach them to a specific user.  You’ll then need to store the parsed logs in a database, so they can easily be queried by the API.  You’ll need to spin up several servers behind a load balancer to process the incoming logs.</p>
<p>Most of the issues that you’ll run into will be around reliability and distributed systems.  For example, if you have millions of devices to gather logs from, and variable demand (in the morning, you get a ton of logs, but not as many at midnight), you’ll need a system that can automatically scale your server count up and down.</p>
<p><img class="full-width" src="/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/scaling.png"></p>
<p class="small text-center">Running servers behind a load balancer.  Servers are registered with the load balancer, and the load balancer sends traffic to them based on how busy they are.  This means servers can be added or removed as needed.</p>
<p>Roughly, the operations in a data pipeline consist of the following phases:</p>
<ul>
<li>Ingestion — this involves gathering in the needed data.</li>
<li>Processing — this involves processing the data to get the end results you want.</li>
<li>Storage — this involves storing the end results for fast retrieval.</li>
<li>Access — you’ll need to enable a tool or user to access the end results of the pipeline.</li>
</ul>
<p><img class="full-width" src="/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/pipeline.png"></p>
<p class="small text-center">A data pipeline — input data is transformed in a series of phases into output data.</p>
<h3 id="findingbadqualityrides">Finding bad quality rides</h3>
<p>For a more complex example, imagine that a data scientist wants to build a system that finds all rides that ended prematurely due to app or driver issues.  One way to do this is to look at the customer service database to see which rides ended with issues, and analyze their language logn with some data about the ride.</p>
<p>Before the data scientist can do this, they need a way to match up the logs in the customer service database with specific rides.  As a data engineer, you’ll want to create an API endpoint that allows the data scientist to query for all customer service messages related to a particular ride.  In order to do this, you’ll need to:</p>
<ul>
<li>Create a system that pulls data from the ride database, and figures out information about the ride, such as how long it was, and whether the destination matched the user’s initial request.</li>
<li>Combine the computed statistics on each ride with user information, such as name and user id.</li>
<li>Extract error information from the app and server analytics logs pertaining to the user during the time period of the ride.</li>
<li>Find all customer service queries by a user.</li>
<li>Create some heuristic to match rides with customer service queries (a simple example is that a customer service query is always about the previous ride)</li>
<li>Store values as needed to ensure that the API performs quickly, even for future rides.</li>
<li>Create an API that returns all customer service messages related to a particular ride.</li>
</ul>
<p>A skilled data engineer will be able to build a pipeline that performs each of the above steps every time a new ride is added.  This will ensure that the data served by the API is always up to date, and that whatever analysis the data scientist does is valid.</p>
<h3 id="dataengineeringskills">Data engineering skills</h3>
<p>A data engineer needs to be good at:</p>
<ul>
<li>Architecting distributed systems</li>
<li>Creating reliable pipelines</li>
<li>Combining data sources</li>
<li>Architecting data stores</li>
<li>Collaborating with data science teams and building the right solutions for them</li>
</ul>
<p>Note that we didn’t mention any tools above.  Although tools like Hadoop and Spark and languages like Scala and Python are important to data engineering, it’s more important to understand the concepts well and know how to build real-world systems.  We’ll continue this focus on concepts over tools throughout this series on data engineering.</p>
<h2 id="dataengineeringroles">Data Engineering Roles</h2>
<p>Although data engineers need to have the skills listed above, the day to day of a data engineer will vary depending on the type of company they work for.  Broadly, you can classify data engineers into a few categories:</p>
<ul>
<li>Generalist</li>
<li>Pipeline-centric</li>
<li>Database-centric</li>
</ul>
<p>Let’s go through each one of these categories.</p>
<h3 id="generalist">Generalist</h3>
<p>A generalist data engineer typically works on a small team.  Without a data engineer, data analysts and scientsts don’t have anything to analyze, making a data engineer a critical first member of a data science team.</p>
<p>When a data engineer is the only data-focused person at a company, they usually end up having to do more end-to-end work.  For example, a generalist data engineer may have to do everything from ingesting the data to processing it to doing the final analysis.  This requires more data science skill than most data engineers have.  However, it also requires less systems architecture knowledge — small teams and companies don’t have a ton of users, so engineering for scale isn’t as important.  This is a good role for a data scientist who wants to transition into data engineering.</p>
<p>When our hypothetical Uber competitor, Rebu, is small, a data engineer might be asked to create a dashboard that shows the number of rides taken for each day in the past month, along with a forecast for the next month.</p>
<h3 id="pipelinecentric">Pipeline-centric</h3>
<p>Pipeline-centric data engineers tend to be necessary in mid-sized companies that have complex data science needs.  A pipeline-centric data engineer will work with teams of data scientists to transform data into a useful format for analysis.  This entails in-depth knowledge of distributed systems and computer science.</p>
<p>As Rebu grows, a pipeline-centric data engineer might be asked to create a tool that enables data scientists to query metadata about rides to use in a predictive algorithm.</p>
<h3 id="databasecentric">Database-centric</h3>
<p>A database-centric data engineer is focused on setting up and populating analytics databases.  This involves some work with pipelines, but more work with tuning databases for fast analysis and creating table schemas.  This involves <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extract,_transform,_load">ETL</a> work to get data into <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_warehouse">warehouses</a>.  This type of data engineer is usually found at larger companies with many data analysts that have their data distributed across databases.</p>
<p>After Rebu takes over the world, a database centric data engineer might design an analytics database, then create scripts to pull information from the main app database into the analytics database.</p>
<p><img class="full-width" src="/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/warehouse.jpg"></p>
<p class="small text-center">A data warehouse takes in data, then makes it easy for others to query it.</p>
<h2 id="dataengineeringskills">Data Engineering Skills</h2>
<p>In this post, we covered data engineering and the skills needed to practice it at a high level.  If you’re interested in architecting large-scale systems, or working with huge amounts of data, then data engineering is a good field for you.</p>
<p>It can be very exciting to see your autoscaling data pipeline suddently handle a traffic spike, or get to work with machines that have terabytes of RAM.  There’s satisfaction in building a robust system that can work for months or years with minimal tweaking.</p>
<p>Because data engineering is about learning to deal with scale and efficiency, it can be hard to find good practice material on your own.  But don’t give up hope — it’s very possible to learn data engineering on your own and get a job in the field.</p>
<p>We’ve recently launched our new interactive <a href="https://www.dataquest.io/path/data-engineer">Data Engineering Path</a> at Dataquest, designed to teach you the skills you need to become a data engineer.  If you’re interested, you can <a href="https://www.dataquest.io">sign up start learning for free</a>.</p>
</div>
</div></div><div class="thrv_wrapper thrive_leads_shortcode"><div class="thrive-shortcode-config" style="display: none !important;"></div><div class="thrive-shortcode-html"><span style="--tl-form-height-m:753.312px;--tl-form-height-t:785.812px;--tl-form-height-d:785.812px;" class="tl-placeholder-f-type-shortcode_21287 tl-preload-form"><span></span></span></div></div></div></div><div class="tcb_flag" style="display: none"></div>

	/**
	 * Displays toast message from storage, it is used when the user is redirected after login
	 */
	if ( window.sessionStorage ) {
		$( window ).on( 'tcb_after_dom_ready', () => {
			let message = sessionStorage.getItem( 'tcb_toast_message' );

			if ( message ) {
				tcbToast( sessionStorage.getItem( 'tcb_toast_message' ), false );
				sessionStorage.removeItem( 'tcb_toast_message' );
			}
		} );
	}

	/**
	 * Displays toast message
	 */
	function tcbToast( message, error, callback ) {
		/* Also allow "message" objects */
		if ( typeof message !== 'string' ) {
			message = message.message || message.error || message.success;
		}
		if ( ! error ) {
			error = false;
		}
		TCB_Front.notificationElement.toggle( message, error ? 'error' : 'success', callback );
	}
} )( typeof ThriveGlobal === 'undefined' ? jQuery : ThriveGlobal.$j );
